channel.title: #rstats on R, it's OK I guess
channel.description: Recent content in #rstats on R, it's OK I guess

item.title: Sampling locations in a city
item.description: yes Introduction Do you follow @londonmapbot on Twitter? You should. Every so often a satellite photo is posted of somewhere in London (the one in England), with the implied invitation to guess where it is. Along with the tweet is a link to openstreetmap, and if you click on it, it gives you a map of where the photo is, so you can see whether your guess was right.

item.title: Another tidying problem
item.description: yes Packages library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ──────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.2 ✓ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✓ tibble 3.0.3 ✓ dplyr 1.0.2 ## ✓ tidyr 1.1.2 ✓ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✓ readr 1.3.1 ✓ forcats 0.5.0 ## ── Conflicts ─────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() Introduction Some cars have a computer that records gas mileage since the last time the computer was reset.

item.title: Two header rows and other spreadsheets
item.description: Packages library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.2.1 ✔ purrr 0.3.2 ## ✔ tibble 2.1.3 ✔ dplyr 0.8.3 ## ✔ tidyr 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✔ readr 1.3.1 ✔ forcats 0.4.0 ## ── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() Introduction A friend tells you that they are trying to find out which combination of detergent and temperature gets the most dirt off their laundry.

item.title: Some things I learned today
item.description: Today (or, at least, recently) I learned: Stan You can open up a .stan file of Stan code in R Studio, and the syntax gets nicely highlighted for you. Also, there is a Check button, which checks that your file is syntactically correct before you try to compile it. In addition, I finally got my head around (fixed effects) ANOVA Bayesian-style, but that is a blog post for another time.

item.title: Estimating sigma using quantiles
item.description: Packages There will be some R later, with some random number generation. I set the random number seed for reproducibility: library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.1.0 ✔ purrr 0.3.0 ## ✔ tibble 2.0.1 ✔ dplyr 0.7.8 ## ✔ tidyr 0.8.2 ✔ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✔ readr 1.3.1 ✔ forcats 0.3.0 ## ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() set.

item.title: My first go at Xaringan
item.description: I had a go at Xaringan to make a small and pointless presentation. Here is the presentation, and here is the R Markdown that produced it. The whole Github repo is an R Studio project. Feel free to clone it and play with it. I got the pdf of the presentation by printing the HTML to pdf in Chrome. (It seems to be easier to share the pdf than share the HTML, because the latter requires extra stuff with it.
